desc.size: Shrub, to 1.5 m tall. Slender, sparingly branched; branches ascending.

part.partText: yellowish to light brown or reddish brown, smooth.
reddish brown, conical, pointed, flattened, appressed to the stem.

alternate; no stipules; with 2 - 7 mm long leafstalks; green above, whitish-waxy beneath, 2 - 8 cm long, 0.5 - 3 cm wide, narrowly or broadly elliptic to lanceolate to reverse egg-shaped, base tapering, tip blunt to rounded or pointed, margins non-toothed, margins slightly down-curved (revolute); finely net-veined on both sides (raised), primary lateral veins parallel; at first silky, becoming smooth.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy, cylindrical catkins on short, leafy stalks; female catkins greenish or reddish, to 3 cm long, scales yellowish brown; male catkins 1 - 2 cm long, scales yellowish brown, stamens 2; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in crowded, elongated clusters; stalked, brownish, 4 - 7 mm long, flask-shaped, smooth; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix pedicellaris is distinguished from most other willows in the Chicago Region by having hairless leaves and down-curved (revolute) leaf margins that are not distinctly toothed. Salix humilis var. humilis and S. humilis var. tristis both have leaves similar to S. pedicellaris; however, the leaves of S. pedicellaris are finely net-veined on both sides and have parallel primary lateral veins.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Local in bogs. Also grows in fens.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow.
